**Baku** ( [US](/wiki/American_English "American English"): [/bɑːˈkuː, ˈbɑːkuː/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"), [UK](/wiki/British_English "British English"): [/bæˈkuː, ˈbækuː/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English");^[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)^^[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)^ [Azerbaijani](/wiki/Azerbaijani_language "Azerbaijani language"): *Bakı* [\[bɑˈcɯ\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Azerbaijani "Help:IPA/Azerbaijani") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/f/f0/Az-baku.ogg/Az-baku.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Az-baku.ogg "File:Az-baku.ogg")^) is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_city "Capital city") and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Azerbaijan "List of cities in Azerbaijan") of [Azerbaijan](/wiki/Azerbaijan "Azerbaijan"), as well as the largest city on the [Caspian Sea](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea") and in the [Caucasus](/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus") region.^[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)^ Baku is 28 metres (92 ft) below [sea level](/wiki/Sea_level "Sea level"), which makes it the [lowest lying national capital in the world](/wiki/List_of_capital_cities_by_elevation "List of capital cities by elevation") and also the largest city in the world below sea level. Baku lies on the southern shore of the [Absheron Peninsula](/wiki/Absheron_Peninsula "Absheron Peninsula"), on the [Bay of Baku](/wiki/Bay_of_Baku "Bay of Baku"). Baku's [urban population](/wiki/Urban_population "Urban population") was estimated at two million people as of 2009.^[\[10\]](#cite_note-pop-10)^ Baku is the [primate city](/wiki/Primate_city "Primate city") of Azerbaijan---it is the sole metropolis in the country, and about 25% of all inhabitants of the country live in Baku's [metropolitan area](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area").{#cite_ref-pop_10-0}

Baku is divided into [twelve administrative raions](#Administrative_divisions) and 48 townships. Among these are the townships on the islands of the [Baku Archipelago](/wiki/Baku_Archipelago "Baku Archipelago"), as well as the industrial settlement of [Neft Daşları](/wiki/Neft_Da%C5%9Flar%C4%B1 "Neft Daşları") built on oil rigs 60 kilometres (37 miles) away from Baku city in the Caspian Sea. The [Old City](/wiki/Old_City_(Baku) "Old City (Baku)"), containing the [Palace of the Shirvanshahs](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Shirvanshahs "Palace of the Shirvanshahs") and the [Maiden Tower](/wiki/Maiden_Tower_(Baku) "Maiden Tower (Baku)"), was designated as a UNESCO [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") in 2000.^[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)^{#cite_ref-11}

The city is the scientific, cultural, and industrial centre of Azerbaijan. Many sizeable Azerbaijani institutions have their headquarters there. In the 2010s, Baku became a venue for major international events. It hosted the [57th Eurovision Song Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2012 "Eurovision Song Contest 2012") in 2012, the [2015 European Games](/wiki/2015_European_Games "2015 European Games"), 4th [Islamic Solidarity Games](/wiki/Islamic_Solidarity_Games "Islamic Solidarity Games"), the [European Grand Prix](/wiki/European_Grand_Prix "European Grand Prix") in 2016, the [Azerbaijan Grand Prix](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Grand_Prix "Azerbaijan Grand Prix") since 2017, the [final](/wiki/2019_UEFA_Europa_League_Final "2019 UEFA Europa League Final") of the [2018--19 UEFA Europa League](/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Europa_League "2018–19 UEFA Europa League"), [UEFA Euro 2020](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020 "UEFA Euro 2020") and [2024 United Nations Climate Change Conference](/wiki/2024_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference "2024 United Nations Climate Change Conference").^[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)^^[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)^ The [Baku International Sea Trade Port](/wiki/Port_of_Baku "Port of Baku") is capable of handling two million tonnes of general and dry bulk cargoes per year.^[\[14\]](#cite_note-14)^ Baku is renowned for its harsh winds, reflected in its nickname, the "City of Winds".{#cite_ref-14}  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]

Baku is long attested under the [Perso-Arabic](/wiki/Perso-Arabic "Perso-Arabic") name باکو (*Bākū* ). Early [Arabic](/wiki/Arabic "Arabic") sources also refer to the city as *Bākuh* and *Bākuya* ,^[\[15\]](#cite_note-15)^ all of which seem to come from a [Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language") name.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ The further etymology is unclear.{#cite_ref-15}

A [popular etymology](/wiki/Folk_etymology "Folk etymology")^[\[16\]](#cite_note-16)^ in the 19th century considered it to be derived from Persian بادکوبه (*Bâd-kube* , meaning "wind-pounded city", a compound of *bād* , "wind", and *kube* ,^[\[17\]](#cite_note-17)^ which is rooted in the verb کوبیدن *kubidan* , "to pound", thus referring to a place where wind would be strong and pounding,^[\[18\]](#cite_note-Web.archive.org-18)^ as is the case of Baku, which is known to experience fierce winter snow storms and harsh winds). This popular name (*Badkubə* in modern Azerbaijani script) gained currency as a nickname for the city by the 19th century (e.g., it is used in *[Akinchi](/wiki/Akinchi "Akinchi")* , volume 1, issue 1, p. 1), and is also reflected in the city's modern nickname as the "City of Winds" (Azerbaijani: *Küləklər şəhəri* ). Another and even less probable folk etymology explains the name as deriving from *Baghkuy* , meaning "God's town". *Baga* (now *بغ* *bagh* ) and *kuy* are the [Old Persian](/wiki/Old_Persian_language "Old Persian language") words for "god" and "town" respectively; the name *Baghkuy* may be compared with *[Baghdād](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad")* ("God-given") in which *dād* is the Old Persian word for "give".{#cite_ref-Web.archive.org_18-0}

During [Soviet rule](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic"), the city was spelled in Cyrillic as "Бакы" in Azerbaijani (while the [Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language") spelling was and still is "Баку", **Baku** ). The modern Azerbaijani spelling, which has been using the Latin alphabet since 1991, is *Bakı*; the shift from the Perso-Arabic letter و (*ū* ) to Cyrillic "ы" and, later, Latin "ı" may be compared to that in other Azerbaijani words (e.g. compare [قاپو](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%BE%D9%88#Azerbaijani "wikt:قاپو") *qāpū* in old Perso-Arabic spelling with modern Azerbaijani *[qapı](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/qap%C4%B1#Azerbaijani "wikt:qapı")* , "door") or in suffixes, as و was often used to transcribe the [vowel harmony](/wiki/Vowel_harmony "Vowel harmony") in Azerbaijani (which was also the practice in [Ottoman Turkish](/wiki/Ottoman_Turkish_language "Ottoman Turkish language")). (See also [Azerbaijani alphabet](/wiki/Azerbaijani_alphabet "Azerbaijani alphabet").)  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main articles: [History of Baku](/wiki/History_of_Baku "History of Baku") and [Timeline of Baku](/wiki/Timeline_of_Baku "Timeline of Baku")  

### Antiquity {#Antiquity}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Antiquity")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Qobustan_inscription.jpg/220px-Qobustan_inscription.jpg)](/wiki/File:Qobustan_inscription.jpg) Roman stone inscription in [Gobustan](/wiki/Gobustan_State_Historical_and_Cultural_Reserve "Gobustan State Historical and Cultural Reserve") dating back to AD 84--96

Traces of human settlement in the region of present-day Baku date back to the [Stone Age](/wiki/Stone_Age "Stone Age"). [Bronze Age](/wiki/Bronze_Age "Bronze Age") rock carvings have been discovered near Bayil, and a bronze figure of a small fish in the territory of the Old City. These have led some to suggest the existence of a Bronze-Age settlement within the city's territory.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-19)^ Near [Nardaran](/wiki/Nardaran "Nardaran"), a place called Umid Gaya features a prehistoric observatory, where images of the sun and of various constellations are carved into rock together with a primitive astronomic table.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-20)^ Further archeological excavations have revealed various prehistoric settlements, native temples, statues and other artifacts within the territory of the modern city and around it.{#cite_ref-20}

In the 1st century AD, the [Romans](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") organised two Caucasian campaigns and reached what is today Baku. Near the city, in what is today [Gobustan](/wiki/Gobustan_State_Historical_and_Cultural_Reserve "Gobustan State Historical and Cultural Reserve"), Roman inscriptions dating from AD 84 to 96 survive -- some of the earliest written evidences for a city there.^[\[21\]](#cite_note-21)^{#cite_ref-21}

According to the 6th-century archbishop and historian St. Sophronius of Cyprus, in 71, St. [Bartholomew the Apostle](/wiki/Bartholomew_the_Apostle "Bartholomew the Apostle") was preaching Christianity in the city of Albana or Albanopolis,^[\[22\]](#cite_note-22)^ associated with present-day Baku^[\[23\]](#cite_note-23)^ or [Derbent](/wiki/Derbent "Derbent"),^[\[24\]](#cite_note-24)^ both located by the [Caspian Sea](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea"). St. Bartholomew managed to convert even members of the local royal family who had worshipped the idol [Astaroth](/wiki/Astaroth "Astaroth"), but was later martyred by being [flayed](/wiki/Flaying "Flaying") alive and crucified head down on orders from the pagan king Astyages.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-25)^ The remains of St. Bartholomew were secretly transferred to [Mesopotamia](/wiki/Mesopotamia "Mesopotamia").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}  

### Rise of the Shirvanshahs and the Safavid era {#Rise_of_the_Shirvanshahs_and_the_Safavid_era}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Rise of the Shirvanshahs and the Safavid era")\]  
See also: [Shirvanshah](/wiki/Shirvanshah "Shirvanshah")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/1541-Battle_in_the_war_between_Shah_Isma%27il_and_the_King_of_Shirvan-Shahnama-i-Isma%27il.jpg/190px-1541-Battle_in_the_war_between_Shah_Isma%27il_and_the_King_of_Shirvan-Shahnama-i-Isma%27il.jpg)](/wiki/File:1541-Battle_in_the_war_between_Shah_Isma%27il_and_the_King_of_Shirvan-Shahnama-i-Isma%27il.jpg) A [miniature painting](/wiki/Miniature_(illuminated_manuscript) "Miniature (illuminated manuscript)") marking the downfall of the [Shirvanshahs](/wiki/Shirvanshahs "Shirvanshahs") at the hands of the [Safavids](/wiki/Safavids "Safavids")

Baku was the realm of the [Shirvanshahs](/wiki/Shirvanshahs "Shirvanshahs") during the 8th century AD. The city frequently came under assault from the [Khazars](/wiki/Khazars "Khazars") and (starting from the 10th century) from the [Rus'](/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27 "Kievan Rus'"). [Akhsitan I](/wiki/Akhsitan_I "Akhsitan I") built a navy in Baku and successfully repelled a Rus' assault in 1170. After a devastating earthquake struck [Shamakhi](/wiki/Shamakhi "Shamakhi"), the capital of [Shirvan](/wiki/Shirvan "Shirvan"), Shirvanshah's court moved to Baku in 1191.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-27)^{#cite_ref-27}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Sabayil_relics.jpg/220px-Sabayil_relics.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sabayil_relics.jpg) Relics from the sunken [Sabayil Castle](/wiki/Sabayil_Castle "Sabayil Castle")

The Shirvan era greatly influenced Baku and the remainder of present-day Azerbaijan. Between the 12th and 14th centuries, massive fortifications were built in Baku and the surrounding towns. The [Maiden Tower](/wiki/Maiden_Tower_(Baku) "Maiden Tower (Baku)"), the [Ramana Tower](/wiki/Ramana_Tower "Ramana Tower"), the [Nardaran Fortress](/wiki/Nardaran_Fortress "Nardaran Fortress"), the Shagan Castle, the [Mardakan Castle](/wiki/Quadrangular_castle_(Mardakan) "Quadrangular castle (Mardakan)"), the [Round Castle](/wiki/Round_Castle_(Mardakan) "Round Castle (Mardakan)") and also the [Sabayil Castle](/wiki/Sabayil_Castle "Sabayil Castle") on the island of the [Bay of Baku](/wiki/Bay_of_Baku "Bay of Baku") date from this period. The [city walls of Baku](/wiki/Old_City_(Baku) "Old City (Baku)") were also rebuilt and strengthened.

By the early 16th century, Baku's wealth and strategic position attracted the attention of its larger neighbours; in the previous two centuries, it was under the rule of the Iran-centred [Kara Koyunlu](/wiki/Kara_Koyunlu "Kara Koyunlu") and [Ak Koyunlu](/wiki/Ak_Koyunlu "Ak Koyunlu"). The fall of the Ak Koyunlu brought the city immediately into the sphere of the newly formed Iranian [Safavid dynasty](/wiki/Safavid_dynasty "Safavid dynasty"), led by king (*[shah](/wiki/Shah "Shah")* ) [Ismail I](/wiki/Ismail_I "Ismail I") ( 1501--1524). Ismail I laid siege to Baku in 1501 and captured it; he allowed the Shirvanshahs to remain in power, under Safavid suzerainty. His successor, king [Tahmasp I](/wiki/Tahmasp_I "Tahmasp I") ( 1524--1576), completely removed the Shirvanshahs from power and made Baku a part of the [Shirvan](/wiki/Safavid_Shirvan "Safavid Shirvan") province. Baku remained as an integral part of his empire and of successive Iranian dynasties for the next centuries, until ceded to the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") through the 1813 [Treaty of Gulistan](/wiki/Treaty_of_Gulistan "Treaty of Gulistan"). The House of Shirvan, which had ruled Baku since the 9th century, was extinguished in the course of Safavid rule.

At this time, the city was enclosed within lines of strong walls, which were washed by the sea on one side and protected by a wide trench on land. The Ottomans briefly gained control over Baku as a result of the [Ottoman-Safavid War of 1578--1590](/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Safavid_War_(1578%E2%80%931590) "Ottoman–Safavid War (1578–1590)"); by 1607, it came under Iranian control again.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-28)^ In 1604 Shah [Abbas I](/wiki/Abbas_I_of_Persia "Abbas I of Persia") ( 1588--1629) destroyed Baku fortress.{#cite_ref-28}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Ateshgah_temple_inscription.png/170px-Ateshgah_temple_inscription.png)](/wiki/File:Ateshgah_temple_inscription.png) [Atashgah](/wiki/Ateshgah_of_Baku "Ateshgah of Baku") is a temple built by Indian traders before 1745, west of the Caspian Sea. The inscription invokes Lord [Shiva](/wiki/Shiva "Shiva") in [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit "Sanskrit") at the Atashgah.

Baku had a reputation as a focal point for traders from across the world during the [Early modern period](/wiki/Early_modern_period "Early modern period"); commerce was active and the area prospered. Notably, traders from the [Indian subcontinent](/wiki/Indian_subcontinent "Indian subcontinent") established themselves in the region. These Indian traders built the [Ateshgah of Baku](/wiki/Ateshgah_of_Baku "Ateshgah of Baku") during 17th--18th centuries; the temple was used as a [Hindu](/wiki/Hindu "Hindu"), [Sikh](/wiki/Sikh "Sikh"), and [Zoroastrian](/wiki/Zoroastrian "Zoroastrian") place of worship.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-Ziyadov2012-29)^{#cite_ref-Ziyadov2012_29-0}  

### Downfall of the Safavids and the Khanate of Baku {#Downfall_of_the_Safavids_and_the_Khanate_of_Baku}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Downfall of the Safavids and the Khanate of Baku")\]

The Safavids temporarily lost power in Iran in 1722; Emperor [Peter the Great](/wiki/Peter_the_Great "Peter the Great") of Russia took advantage of the situation and invaded. As a result of the [Russo-Persian War of 1722--1723](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_of_1722%E2%80%931723 "Russo-Persian War of 1722–1723"), the Safavids were forced to cede Baku to Russia.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-30)^ By 1730 the situation had deteriorated for the Russians; the successes of [Nader Shah](/wiki/Nader_Shah "Nader Shah") ( 1736--1747) led them to sign the [Treaty of Ganja](/wiki/Treaty_of_Ganja "Treaty of Ganja") near [Ganja](/wiki/Ganja,_Azerbaijan "Ganja, Azerbaijan") on 10 March 1735, ceding the city and all other conquered territories in the Caucasus back to [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran").^[\[31\]](#cite_note-31)^{#cite_ref-31}

The eruption of instability following Nader Shah's death in 1747 gave rise to the various [Caucasian khanates](/wiki/Khanates_of_the_Caucasus "Khanates of the Caucasus"). The semi-autonomous Persian-ruled^[\[32\]](#cite_note-32)^^[\[33\]](#cite_note-33)^{#cite_ref-33}  

### Russo-Persian Wars and Iran's cession {#Russo-Persian_Wars_and_Iran.27s_cession}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Russo-Persian Wars and Iran's cession")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83._%D0%9D%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F._1861.jpg/270px-%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83._%D0%9D%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F._1861.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%91%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%83._%D0%9D%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B6%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F._1861.jpg) Painting of Baku's shoreline in 1861 by [Alexey Bogolyubov](/wiki/Alexey_Bogolyubov "Alexey Bogolyubov")

From the late 18th century, Imperial Russia switched to a more aggressive geopolitical stance towards its two neighbours and rivals to the south, namely Iran and the Ottoman Empire. In the spring of 1796, by [Catherine II](/wiki/Catherine_II_of_Russia "Catherine II of Russia")'s order, General [Valerian Zubov](/wiki/Valerian_Zubov "Valerian Zubov")'s troops started [a large campaign](/wiki/Persian_Expedition_of_1796 "Persian Expedition of 1796") against [Qajar](/wiki/Qajar_dynasty "Qajar dynasty") Persia.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-34)^ Zubov had sent 13,000 men to capture Baku, and it was overrun subsequently without any resistance. On 13 June 1796, a Russian flotilla entered Baku Bay, and a garrison of Russian troops was stationed inside the city. Later, however, Emperor [Paul I](/wiki/Paul_I_of_Russia "Paul I of Russia") of Russia ordered the cessation of the campaign and the withdrawal of Russian forces following the death of his predecessor, [Catherine the Great](/wiki/Catherine_the_Great "Catherine the Great"). In March 1797 the tsarist troops left Baku and the city became part of [Qajar Iran](/wiki/Qajar_Iran "Qajar Iran") again.{#cite_ref-34}

In 1813, following the [Russo-Persian War of 1804--1813](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1804%E2%80%9313) "Russo-Persian War (1804–13)"), Qajar Iran had to sign the [Treaty of Gulistan](/wiki/Treaty_of_Gulistan "Treaty of Gulistan") with Russia this provided for the cession of Baku and of most of Iran's territories in the [North Caucasus](/wiki/North_Caucasus "North Caucasus") and [South Caucasus](/wiki/South_Caucasus "South Caucasus") to Russia. During the next and final bout of hostilities between the two, the [Russo-Persian War of 1826--1828](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1826%E2%80%9328) "Russo-Persian War (1826–28)"), the Iranians briefly recaptured Baku. However, the militarily superior Russians ended this war with a victory as well, and the resulting [Treaty of Turkmenchay](/wiki/Treaty_of_Turkmenchay "Treaty of Turkmenchay") (1828) made Baku's inclusion in the [Russian Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") definite.^[\[35\]](#cite_note-35)^ When Baku was occupied by the Russian troops during the [war of 1804--13](/wiki/Russo-Persian_War_(1804%E2%80%9313) "Russo-Persian War (1804–13)"), nearly the entire population of some 8,000 people was ethnic [Tat](/wiki/Tat_people_(Caucasus) "Tat people (Caucasus)").^[\[36\]](#cite_note-books.google.nl-36)^ Baku within Russia was the administrative center of the [Baku Uyezd](/wiki/Baku_Uyezd "Baku Uyezd"), [Baku Governorate](/wiki/Baku_Governorate "Baku Governorate"), and the [Baku Gradonachalstvo](/wiki/Baku_Gradonachalstvo "Baku Gradonachalstvo").{#cite_ref-books.google.nl_36-0}  

### Discovery of oil {#Discovery_of_oil}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Discovery of oil")\]  
Main article: [Petroleum industry in Azerbaijan](/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Azerbaijan "Petroleum industry in Azerbaijan")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/BibiEybat.jpg/270px-BibiEybat.jpg)](/wiki/File:BibiEybat.jpg) Oil workers digging an oil well by hand at Bibi-Heybat

The Russians built the first [oil-distilling factory](/wiki/Oil_refinery "Oil refinery") in [Balaxani](/wiki/Balaxani "Balaxani") in 1837. The first person to drill oil in Baku was an ethnic [Armenian](/wiki/Armenians "Armenians") [Ivan Mirzoev](/wiki/Ivan_Mirzoev "Ivan Mirzoev"), who is also known as a 'founding father of Baku's oil industry.'^[\[37\]](#cite_note-37)^^[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)^ Digging for oil began in the 1840s, with the first [oil well](/wiki/Oil_well "Oil well") drilled in the [Bibi-Heybat](/wiki/Bibiheyb%C9%99t "Bibiheybət") suburb of Baku in 1846.^[\[39\]](#cite_note-Smil-39)^ Large-scale [oil exploration](/wiki/Oil_exploration "Oil exploration") started in 1872 when the Russian imperial authorities auctioned parcels of oil-rich land around Baku to private investors. The pioneer of oil extracting from the bottom of the sea was the Polish geologist [Witold Zglenicki](/wiki/Witold_Zglenicki "Witold Zglenicki"). Soon after, investors appeared in Baku, including the [Nobel Brothers](/wiki/Nobel_Brothers "Nobel Brothers") in 1873 and the [Rothschilds](/wiki/Rothschild_family "Rothschild family") in 1882. An industrial area of oil refineries, better known as [Black Town](/wiki/Black_City_(Baku) "Black City (Baku)") ([Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language"): Чёрный город), developed near Baku by the early 1880s.^[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)^{#cite_ref-40}

Professor [A. V. Williams Jackson](/wiki/A._V._Williams_Jackson "A. V. Williams Jackson") of Columbia University wrote in his work *From Constantinople to the Home of Omar Khayyam* (1911):
> Baku is a city founded upon oil, for to its inexhaustible founts of naphtha it owes its very existence, its maintenance, its prosperity... At present Baku produces one-fifth of the oil that is used in the world, and the immense output in crude petroleum from this single city far surpasses that in any other district where oil is found. Verily, the words of the Scriptures find illustration here: 'the rock poured me out rivers of oil. Oil is in the air one breathes, in one's nostrils, in one's eyes, in the water of the morning bath (though not in the drinking water, for that is brought in bottles from distant mineral springs), in one's starched linen -- everywhere. This is the impression one carries away from Baku, and it is certainly true in the environs.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}

By the beginning of the 20th century, half of the oil sold in international markets was extracted in Baku.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-42)^ The [oil boom](/wiki/Oil_boom "Oil boom") contributed to the massive growth of Baku. Between 1856 and 1910 Baku's population grew at a faster rate than that of [London](/wiki/London "London"), [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris"), [New York](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City"), or [Tokyo](/wiki/Tokyo "Tokyo").{#cite_ref-42}  

### World War I {#World_War_I}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: World War I")\]  
Main article: [Baku during World War I](/wiki/Baku_during_World_War_I "Baku during World War I")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Army_of_Azerbaijan_in_1918.jpg/220px-Army_of_Azerbaijan_in_1918.jpg)](/wiki/File:Army_of_Azerbaijan_in_1918.jpg) Soldiers and officers of the army of the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic shortly after the [Battle of Baku](/wiki/Battle_of_Baku "Battle of Baku") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Neftchiler_Avenue_1918-1920.jpg/220px-Neftchiler_Avenue_1918-1920.jpg)](/wiki/File:Neftchiler_Avenue_1918-1920.jpg) [Neftchiler Avenue](/wiki/Neftchiler_Avenue "Neftchiler Avenue") in Baku,  1920

In 1917, after the [October Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution") and amidst the turmoil of [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") and the [Russian Revolution](/wiki/Russian_Revolution "Russian Revolution"), Baku came under the control of the [Baku Commune](/wiki/26_Baku_Commissars "26 Baku Commissars"), led by the veteran Bolshevik [Stepan Shahumyan](/wiki/Stepan_Shahumyan "Stepan Shahumyan"). Seeking to capitalize on the existing ethnic conflicts, by spring 1918, Bolsheviks inspired and condoned civil war in and around Baku. During the [March Days](/wiki/March_Days "March Days") of 1918, Bolsheviks and [Dashnaks](/wiki/Armenian_Revolutionary_Federation "Armenian Revolutionary Federation"), seeking to establish control over Baku streets, faced armed Azerbaijani groups. The Azerbaijanis suffered defeat from the united forces of the Baku Soviet and were massacred by Dashnak teams in what was called the [March Days](/wiki/March_Days "March Days"). An estimated 3,000--12,000 Azerbaijanis were killed in their own capital.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-smithmusavat-43)^^[\[44\]](#cite_note-minahan-44)^ After the massacre, on 28 May 1918, the Azerbaijani faction of the [Transcaucasian Sejm](/wiki/Transcaucasian_Democratic_Federative_Republic "Transcaucasian Democratic Federative Republic") proclaimed the independence of the [Azerbaijan Democratic Republic](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Democratic_Republic "Azerbaijan Democratic Republic") (ADR) in [Ganja](/wiki/Ganja,_Azerbaijan "Ganja, Azerbaijan"), thereby founding the first Muslim-majority [democratic](/wiki/Democratic_republic "Democratic republic") and [secular](/wiki/Secular "Secular") [republic](/wiki/Republic "Republic").^[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)^ The newly independent Azerbaijani republic, being unable to defend the independence of the country on their own, asked the Ottoman Empire for military support in accordance with clause 4 of the treaty between the two countries. Shortly after, Azerbaijani forces, with support of the [Ottoman Army of Islam](/wiki/Ottoman_Army_of_Islam "Ottoman Army of Islam") led by [Nuru Pasha](/wiki/Nuri_Killigil "Nuri Killigil"), started their advance on Baku, eventually capturing the city from the loose coalition of [Bolsheviks](/wiki/Bolshevik "Bolshevik"), [SRs](/wiki/Socialist-Revolutionary_Party "Socialist-Revolutionary Party"), [Dashnaks](/wiki/Armenian_Revolutionary_Federation "Armenian Revolutionary Federation"), [Mensheviks](/wiki/Menshevik "Menshevik") and British forces under the command of General [Lionel Dunsterville](/wiki/Lionel_Dunsterville "Lionel Dunsterville") on 15 September 1918.{#cite_ref-45}

After the [Battle of Baku](/wiki/Battle_of_Baku "Battle of Baku") of August--September 1918, the Azerbaijani irregular troops, with the tacit support of the Turkish command, conducted four days of pillaging and killing 10,000--30,000^[\[46\]](#cite_note-Gen-46)^ [Armenians of Baku](/wiki/Armenians_in_Baku "Armenians in Baku"). This [pogrom](/wiki/Pogrom "Pogrom") became known as the "[September Days](/wiki/September_Days "September Days")". Shortly after this, Baku was proclaimed the new capital of the Azerbaijan Democratic Republic.{#cite_ref-Gen_46-0}

The Ottoman Empire, recognising defeat in World War I by October 1918, signed the [Armistice of Mudros](/wiki/Armistice_of_Mudros "Armistice of Mudros") with the British (30 October 1918); this meant the evacuation of Turkish forces from Baku. Headed by General [William Thomson](/wiki/William_Montgomery_Thomson "William Montgomery Thomson"), some 5,000 British troops, including parts of the former [Dunsterforce](/wiki/Dunsterforce "Dunsterforce"), arrived in Baku on 17 November. Thomson declared himself military governor of Baku and implemented [martial law](/wiki/Martial_law "Martial law") in the city until "the civil power would be strong enough to release the forces from the responsibility to maintain the public order". British forces left before the end of 1919.^[\[47\]](#cite_note-47)^{#cite_ref-47}  

### Soviet period {#Soviet_period}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Soviet period")\]

The independence of the Azerbaijani republic was a significant but short-lived chapter in Baku's history. On 28 April 1920, the [11th Red Army](/wiki/11th_Army_(RSFSR) "11th Army (RSFSR)") [invaded](/wiki/Red_Army_invasion_of_Azerbaijan "Red Army invasion of Azerbaijan") Baku and reinstalled the Bolsheviks, making Baku the capital of the [Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Soviet_Socialist_Republic "Azerbaijan Soviet Socialist Republic").

The city underwent many major changes. As a result, Baku played a great role in many branches of Soviet life. Baku was the major oil city of the Soviet Union. From about 1921 the city was headed by the Baku City Executive Committee, commonly known in Russian as *Bakgorispolkom* . Together with Baku Party Committee (known as the *Baksovet* ), it developed the economic significance of the Caspian metropolis. From 1922 to 1930 Baku became the venue for one of the major [trade fairs](/wiki/Trade_fair "Trade fair") of the Soviet Union, serving as a commercial bridgehead to Iran and the Middle East.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-48)^{#cite_ref-48}  

### World War II {#World_War_II}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: World War II")\]  
Main article: [Baku during World War II](/wiki/Baku_during_World_War_II "Baku during World War II")

The major powers continued to note Baku's growing importance as a major energy hub. During [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") (1939--1945) and particularly during the [1942 Nazi German invasion of the southwestern Soviet Union](/wiki/Case_Blue "Case Blue"), Baku became of vital strategic importance to the [Axis powers](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis powers"). In fact, capturing the [oil fields of Baku](/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Azerbaijan#World_War_II "Petroleum industry in Azerbaijan") was a primary goal of the [Wehrmacht](/wiki/Wehrmacht "Wehrmacht")'s [Operation Edelweiss](/wiki/Operation_Edelweiss "Operation Edelweiss"), carried out between May and November 1942. However, the [German Army](/wiki/German_Army_(1935%E2%80%931945) "German Army (1935–1945)") reached only a point some 530 kilometres (329 miles) northwest of Baku in November 1942, falling far short of the city's capture before being driven back during the Soviet [Operation Little Saturn](/wiki/Operation_Little_Saturn "Operation Little Saturn") in mid-December 1942.  

### Fall of the Soviet Union and later {#Fall_of_the_Soviet_Union_and_later}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Fall of the Soviet Union and later")\]

After the 1991 [dissolution of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet Union"), Baku embarked on a process of restructuring on a scale unseen in its history.^[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)^ Thousands of [panel buildings](/wiki/Khrushchevka "Khrushchevka") from the Soviet period were demolished to make way for a green belt on its shores; parks and gardens were built on the land reclaimed by filling up the beaches of the [Baku Bay](/wiki/Baku_Bay "Baku Bay"). Improvements were made in general cleaning, maintenance, and garbage collection to bring these services up to Western European standards. The city is growing dynamically and developing at pace on an east--west axis along the shores of the [Caspian Sea](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea"). Sustainability has become a key factor in future urban development.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)^{#cite_ref-50}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Baku%2C_Azerbaijan%2C_satellite_image%2C_LandSat-5%2C_2010-09-06.jpg/220px-Baku%2C_Azerbaijan%2C_satellite_image%2C_LandSat-5%2C_2010-09-06.jpg)](/wiki/File:Baku,_Azerbaijan,_satellite_image,_LandSat-5,_2010-09-06.jpg) Absheron Peninsula satellite image, [Landsat 5](/wiki/Landsat_5 "Landsat 5"), 6 September 2010

Baku is situated on the western coast of the [Caspian Sea](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea"). In the vicinity of the city there are a number of [mud volcanoes](/wiki/Mud_volcano "Mud volcano") (Keyraki, Bogkh-bogkha, [Lokbatan](/wiki/Lokbatan "Lokbatan") and others) and [salt lakes](/wiki/Salt_lake "Salt lake") ([Boyukshor](/wiki/Lake_Boyukshor "Lake Boyukshor"), Khodasan, etc.).  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Climate")\]

Baku has a [cold semi-arid climate](/wiki/Cold_semi-arid_climate "Cold semi-arid climate") ([Köppen climate classification](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *BSk* ) with hot and humid summers, cool and occasionally wet winters, and strong winds all year long. However, unlike many other cities with such climate features, Baku does not see extremely hot summers and substantial sunshine hours. This is largely because of its northerly [latitude](/wiki/Latitude "Latitude") and the fact that it is located on a peninsula on the shore of the Caspian Sea.

Baku, and the [Absheron Peninsula](/wiki/Absheron_Peninsula "Absheron Peninsula") on which it is situated, is the most arid part of Azerbaijan ([precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_(meteorology) "Precipitation (meteorology)") here is around or less than 200 mm (8 in) a year). This is largely due to the [rain shadow](/wiki/Rain_shadow "Rain shadow") effect from the [Caucasus Mountains](/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains "Caucasus Mountains"), with corresponding latitudes on the [Black Sea](/wiki/Black_Sea "Black Sea") on average receiving 2,300 mm (91 in) or more. The majority of the light annual precipitation occurs in seasons other than summer, but none of these seasons is particularly wet.

During Soviet times, Baku, with its long hours of sunshine and dry healthy climate, was a vacation destination where citizens could enjoy beaches or relax in now-dilapidated [spa](/wiki/Destination_spa "Destination spa") complexes overlooking the Caspian Sea. The city's past as a Soviet industrial centre left it one of the most polluted cities in the world, as of 2008^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit)^.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-ForbesPollution-51)^{#cite_ref-ForbesPollution_51-0}

At the same time, Baku is noted as a very windy city throughout the year, hence the city's nickname the "[City of Winds](/wiki/City_of_Winds "City of Winds")", and gale-force winds, the cold northern wind *[khazri](/wiki/Khazri "Khazri")* and the warm southern wind *[gilavar](/wiki/Gilavar "Gilavar")* are typical here in all seasons. Indeed, the city is renowned for its fierce winter snow storms and harsh winds.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-Web.archive.org-18)^ The speed of the *khazri* sometimes reaches 144 km/h (89 mph), which can cause damage to crops, trees and roof tiles.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-52)^{#cite_ref-52}

The daily mean temperature in July and August averages 26.4 °C (79.5 °F), and there is very little rainfall during that season. During summer, the *khazri* sweeps through, bringing desired coolness. Winter is cool and occasionally wet, with the daily mean temperature in January and February averaging 4.3 °C (39.7 °F). During winter, the *khazri* sweeps through, driven by polar [air masses](/wiki/Air_mass "Air mass"); temperatures on the coast frequently drop below freezing and make it feel bitterly cold. Winter [snow storms](/wiki/Winter_storm "Winter storm") are occasional; [snow](/wiki/Snow "Snow") usually melts within a few days after each snowfall.

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Demographics")\]

Until 1988, Baku had very large Russian, [Armenian](/wiki/Armenian_people "Armenian people"), and [Jewish](/wiki/Jews "Jews") populations which contributed to [cultural diversity](/wiki/Cultural_diversity "Cultural diversity") and added in various ways (music, literature, architecture and progressive outlook) to Baku's history. With the onset of the [First Nagorno-Karabakh War](/wiki/First_Nagorno-Karabakh_War "First Nagorno-Karabakh War") and the [pogrom against Armenians](/wiki/Pogrom_of_Armenians_in_Baku "Pogrom of Armenians in Baku") starting in January 1990, the city's large Armenian population was expelled.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)^^[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)^ After the [collapse of the Soviet Union](/wiki/Collapse_of_the_Soviet_Union "Collapse of the Soviet Union"), [Azerbaijani President](/wiki/President_of_Azerbaijan "President of Azerbaijan") [Heydar Aliyev](/wiki/Heydar_Aliyev "Heydar Aliyev") returned several synagogues and a Jewish college, nationalised by the Soviets, to the Jewish community; he encouraged the restoration of these buildings. Seven of the original 11 synagogues, including the Gilah synagogue, built in 1896, and the large Kruei Synagogue, were renovated.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)^{#cite_ref-61}

### Ethnic groups {#Ethnic_groups}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Ethnic groups")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/89/Christmas_in_Baku_on_January_6%2C_1904_and_Armenian_church.jpg/220px-Christmas_in_Baku_on_January_6%2C_1904_and_Armenian_church.jpg)](/wiki/File:Christmas_in_Baku_on_January_6,_1904_and_Armenian_church.jpg) The Armenian [Saint Gregory the Illuminator's Church, Baku](/wiki/Saint_Gregory_the_Illuminator%27s_Church,_Baku "Saint Gregory the Illuminator's Church, Baku")

Today, the vast majority of Baku's population is made up of ethnic [Azerbaijanis](/wiki/Azerbaijani_people "Azerbaijani people"), and the rest are [Talysh](/wiki/Talysh_people "Talysh people"), [Russians](/wiki/Russians "Russians"), [Lezgi](/wiki/Lezgins "Lezgins") and others. The intensive growth of the population started in the middle of the 19th century when Baku was a small town with a population of about 7,000 people. The population increased again from about 13,000 in the 1860s to 112,000 in 1897 and 215,000 in 1913, making Baku the largest city in the Caucasus region.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-80)^{#cite_ref-80}

Baku has been a cosmopolitan city at certain times during its history, meaning ethnic Azerbaijanis did not constitute the majority of population.^[\[76\]](#cite_note-81)^ It was only in the 1970s that ethnic Azerbaijanis achieved demographic dominance in Baku.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-82)^ In 2003 Baku additionally had 153,400 [internally displaced persons](/wiki/Internally_displaced_person "Internally displaced person") and 93,400 refugees.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-83)^^[\[79\]](#cite_note-84)^{#cite_ref-84}  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Religion")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8.jpg)](/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B8.jpg) The 13th-century [Bibi-Heybat Mosque](/wiki/Bibi-Heybat_Mosque "Bibi-Heybat Mosque") was built over the tomb of a descendant of the Islamic prophet [Muhammad](/wiki/Muhammad "Muhammad").^[\[80\]](#cite_note-Bibi-85)^

The religion with the largest community of followers is Islam. The majority of the Muslims are [Shia Muslims](/wiki/Shia_Islam "Shia Islam"), and the Republic of Azerbaijan has the second-highest Shia population percentage in the world, after [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran").^[\[81\]](#cite_note-86)^ The city's notable mosques include [Juma Mosque](/wiki/Juma_Mosque_(Baku) "Juma Mosque (Baku)"), [Bibi-Heybat Mosque](/wiki/Bibi-Heybat_Mosque "Bibi-Heybat Mosque"), [Muhammad Mosque](/wiki/Muhammad_Mosque_(Baku) "Muhammad Mosque (Baku)") and [Taza Pir Mosque](/wiki/Taza_Pir_Mosque "Taza Pir Mosque").{#cite_ref-86}

There are some other faiths practised among the different ethnic groups within the country. By article 48 of its [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Azerbaijan "Constitution of Azerbaijan"), Azerbaijan is a [secular state](/wiki/Secular_state "Secular state") and ensures religious freedom. Religious minorities include [Russian Orthodox Christians](/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Christians "Russian Orthodox Christians"), [Catholic Levantines](/wiki/Levantines_(Latin_Christians) "Levantines (Latin Christians)"), [Georgian Orthodox Christians](/wiki/Georgian_Orthodox_Church "Georgian Orthodox Church"), [Albanian-Udi Apostolic Christians](/wiki/Church_of_Caucasian_Albania "Church of Caucasian Albania"), [Lutherans](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism"), [Ashkenazi](/wiki/Azerbaijani_Jews "Azerbaijani Jews") Jews, and [Sufi](/wiki/Sufi "Sufi") Muslims. Baku is the seat of the [Catholic](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church") [Apostolic Prefecture of Azerbaijan](/wiki/Apostolic_Prefecture_of_Azerbaijan "Apostolic Prefecture of Azerbaijan").

[Zoroastrianism](/wiki/Zoroastrianism "Zoroastrianism"), although extinct in the city as well as in the rest of the country by the present time, had a long [history in Azerbaijan](/wiki/Zoroastrianism_in_Azerbaijan "Zoroastrianism in Azerbaijan") and the [Zoroastrian New Year](/wiki/Nowruz "Nowruz") (Nowruz) continues to be the main holiday in the city as well as in the rest of Azerbaijan.  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Economy")\]  
Main article: [Economy of Baku](/wiki/Economy_of_Baku "Economy of Baku")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Heyd%C9%99r_%C6%8Fliyev_prospekti_2022-ci_ild%C9%99.jpg/220px-Heyd%C9%99r_%C6%8Fliyev_prospekti_2022-ci_ild%C9%99.jpg)](/wiki/File:Heyd%C9%99r_%C6%8Fliyev_prospekti_2022-ci_ild%C9%99.jpg) Heydar Aliyev Avenue, home to the headquarters of multiple [publicly](/wiki/Public_company "Public company") owned companies and enterprises in Azerbaijan. Along with the [Bay of Baku](/wiki/Bay_of_Baku "Bay of Baku"), it hosts the majority of the country's [skyscrapers](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Azerbaijan "List of tallest buildings in Azerbaijan") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Iss069e091732.jpg/236px-Iss069e091732.jpg)](/wiki/File:Iss069e091732.jpg) Satellite image of Baku at night

Baku is the economic hub of Azerbaijan, hosting many of the [country's major companies](/wiki/List_of_companies_of_Azerbaijan "List of companies of Azerbaijan") and serving as the center for key industries such as oil and gas, finance, trade, and technology. The city is home to major financial institutions, multinational corporations, and various businesses that contribute to the country's economy. Baku accounts for approximately 65% of Azerbaijan's total [GDP](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product").^[\[82\]](#cite_note-87)^ Azerbaijani [conglomerates](/wiki/Conglomerate_(company) "Conglomerate (company)") such as [PASHA Holding](/wiki/PASHA_Holding "PASHA Holding") which is headquartered in Baku, and [AF Holding](/wiki/AF_Holding "AF Holding"), operate in the city. Baku also attracts a significant portion of the country's [workforce](/wiki/Workforce "Workforce"), with many people relocating for job opportunities and business prospects. As of the end of the first quarter of 2023, 52% of hired workers in Azerbaijan were employed in Baku.^[\[83\]](#cite_note-88)^ In addition to its role as the economic hub, Baku is home to the largest port in the [Caspian](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea") [Sea](/wiki/Caspian_Sea "Caspian Sea"), the [Baku International Sea Trade Port](/wiki/Port_of_Baku "Port of Baku"), more commonly known as Port of Baku.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-89)^ It handles a wide range of [cargo](/wiki/Cargo "Cargo"), including [containers](/wiki/Container "Container"), [bulk goods](/wiki/Bulk_cargo "Bulk cargo"), and liquid cargo, with an annual capacity of 15 million tons of cargo. The port also plays an essential role in the [Trans-Caspian International Transport Route](/wiki/Trans-Caspian_International_Transport_Route "Trans-Caspian International Transport Route"), facilitating trade between [East Asia](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia"), [Central Asia](/wiki/Central_Asia "Central Asia"), [Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"), and the [Caucasus](/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus") through integrated sea, rail, and road transport.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-90)^^[\[86\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c0/Port_Baku_Towers.jpg/220px-Port_Baku_Towers.jpg)](/wiki/File:Port_Baku_Towers.jpg) [Port Baku Towers](/wiki/Port_Baku_Towers "Port Baku Towers"), high-rise office buildings located on [Neftchiler Avenue](/wiki/Neftchilar_Avenue "Neftchilar Avenue")

Baku's largest industry is petroleum, and its petroleum exports make it a large contributor to Azerbaijan's [balance of payments](/wiki/Balance_of_payments "Balance of payments"). The existence of petroleum has been known since the 8th century. In the 10th century, the Arabian traveler, Marudee, reported that both white and black oil were being extracted naturally from Baku.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-92)^ By the 15th century, oil for lamps was obtained from hand-dug surface wells. Commercial exploitation began in 1872, and by the beginning of the 20th century the [Baku oil fields](/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Azerbaijan "Petroleum industry in Azerbaijan") were the largest in the world. Towards the end of the 20th century, much of the onshore petroleum had been exhausted, and drilling had extended into the sea offshore. By the end of the 19th century [skilled workers](/wiki/Skilled_worker "Skilled worker") and specialists flocked to Baku. By 1900 the city had more than 3,000 oil wells, of which 2,000 were producing oil at industrial levels. Baku ranked as one of the largest centres for the production of [oil industry](/wiki/Petroleum_industry "Petroleum industry") equipment before World War II. The World War II [Battle of Stalingrad](/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad "Battle of Stalingrad") was fought to determine who would have control of Baku oil fields. Fifty years before the battle, Baku produced half of the world's oil supply.^[\[88\]](#cite_note-93)^{#cite_ref-93}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Panorama_of_Baku_2022.jpg/220px-Panorama_of_Baku_2022.jpg)](/wiki/File:Panorama_of_Baku_2022.jpg) [The Crescent Development project](/wiki/The_Crescent_Development_project "The Crescent Development project")

The oil economy of Baku is undergoing a resurgence, with the development of the massive [Azeri-Chirag-Guneshli](/wiki/Azeri%E2%80%93Chirag%E2%80%93Guneshli "Azeri–Chirag–Guneshli") field (Shallow water Gunashli by [SOCAR](/wiki/State_Oil_Company_of_Azerbaijan_Republic "State Oil Company of Azerbaijan Republic"), deeper areas by a consortium led by [BP](/wiki/BP "BP")), development of the [Shah Deniz gas field](/wiki/Shah_Deniz_gas_field "Shah Deniz gas field"), the expansion of the [Sangachal Terminal](/wiki/Sangachal_Terminal "Sangachal Terminal") and the construction of the [BTC Pipeline](/wiki/Baku%E2%80%93Tbilisi%E2%80%93Ceyhan_pipeline "Baku–Tbilisi–Ceyhan pipeline"). The [South Caucasus Pipeline](/wiki/South_Caucasus_Pipeline "South Caucasus Pipeline") (SCP), also known as the Baku-Tbilisi-Erzurum Pipeline, transports natural gas from Azerbaijan's [Shah Deniz gas field](/wiki/Shah_Deniz_gas_field "Shah Deniz gas field") to Turkey, with further connections to Europe. Spanning over 690 kilometers, the pipeline has been operational since 2007 and plays a central role in the [Southern Gas Corridor](/wiki/Southern_Gas_Corridor "Southern Gas Corridor"), which aims to diversify Europe's energy sources with an annual export capacity of up to 25 billion cubic metres of gas.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}

The [Baku Stock Exchange](/wiki/Baku_Stock_Exchange "Baku Stock Exchange") is Azerbaijan's largest [stock exchange](/wiki/Stock_exchange "Stock exchange"), and largest in the [Caucasian](/wiki/Caucasus "Caucasus") region by [market capitalization](/wiki/Market_capitalization "Market capitalization"). A relatively large number of transnational companies are headquartered in Baku. One of the more prominent institutions headquartered in Baku is the [International Bank of Azerbaijan](/wiki/International_Bank_of_Azerbaijan "International Bank of Azerbaijan"), which employs over 1,000 people. International banks with branches in Baku include [HSBC](/wiki/HSBC "HSBC"), [Société Générale](/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_G%C3%A9n%C3%A9rale "Société Générale") and [Credit Suisse](/wiki/Credit_Suisse "Credit Suisse").^[\[90\]](#cite_note-95)^{#cite_ref-95}  

### Tourism and shopping {#Tourism_and_shopping}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Tourism and shopping")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/Baku_15_10_08_466000.jpeg/220px-Baku_15_10_08_466000.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Baku_15_10_08_466000.jpeg) Deniz Mall, one of the largest shopping centers in Baku and [South Cacuasus](/wiki/South_Caucasus "South Caucasus") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/New_Baku_Flagpole_Sept_2024.jpg/227px-New_Baku_Flagpole_Sept_2024.jpg)](/wiki/File:New_Baku_Flagpole_Sept_2024.jpg) [National Flag Square](/wiki/National_Flag_Square "National Flag Square") of Baku is home to the largest flag ever raised, towering over the skyline of the capital city  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_03.jpg/225px-Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_03.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_03.jpg)  
Crescent Mall, part of the [Crescent Development project](/wiki/The_Crescent_Development_project "The Crescent Development project")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_02.jpg/225px-Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_02.jpg)

Baku is one of the most important tourist destinations in the Caucasus, with hotels in the city earning 7 million euros in 2009.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-96)^ Many sizable world [hotel chains](/wiki/Hotel_chain "Hotel chain") have a presence in the city. Baku has many popular [tourist and entertainment spots](/wiki/List_of_tourist_attractions_in_Baku "List of tourist attractions in Baku"), such as the downtown [Fountains Square](/wiki/Fountains_Square,_Baku "Fountains Square, Baku"), the One and Thousand Nights Beach, [Shikhov Beach](/wiki/Shikhov_Beach "Shikhov Beach") and [Oil Rocks](/wiki/Oil_Rocks "Oil Rocks"). Baku's vicinities feature [Yanar Dag](/wiki/Yanar_Dag "Yanar Dag"), an ever-blazing spot of natural gas. On 2 September 2010 with the inauguration of [National Flag Square](/wiki/National_Flag_Square "National Flag Square"), Baku set the [world record](/wiki/Guinness_Book_of_Records "Guinness Book of Records") for tallest [flagpole](/wiki/Flagpole "Flagpole");^[\[92\]](#cite_note-97)^^[\[93\]](#cite_note-98)^ on 24 May 2011, the city of [Dushanbe](/wiki/Dushanbe "Dushanbe") in [Tajikistan](/wiki/Tajikistan "Tajikistan") set a new record with a 3 metres (9.8 feet)-higher flagpole.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-99)^ A few years later, the Flag Pole was dismantled and the National Flag Square was closed off with fences. It was opened once again after years of repair on On November 8, 2024, to commemorate the [Victory Day](/wiki/Victory_Day_(Azerbaijan) "Victory Day (Azerbaijan)") over Armenia's forces in [Nagorno-Karabakh](/wiki/Nagorno-Karabakh "Nagorno-Karabakh") region of Azerbaijan. The National Flag Square features a museum, with a collection of about 400 items, along with flags of Khanates and Empires that have been prevalent in the region.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-100)^{#cite_ref-100}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_01.jpg/220px-Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Opening_of_Crescent_Mall_01.jpg) Back area of the Crescent Mall

Baku has several shopping malls, including Ganjlik Mall, Deniz Mall, Crescent Mall, Port Baku Mall, 28 Mall, [Park Bulvar](/wiki/Park_Bulvar "Park Bulvar"), City Park and Metro Park. The retail areas contain shops from chain stores up to high-end boutiques. Ganjlik Mall particularly stands out, as it is the largest mall in the city of Baku.^[\[96\]](#cite_note-101)^ Crescent Mall is the newest shopping center in Baku, opening on May 28, 2024. It adds to the city's growing collection of malls, bringing a variety of stores, restaurants, and entertainment options to the area.^[\[97\]](#cite_note-102)^{#cite_ref-102}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Ta%C4%9F%C4%B1yev_qarda%C5%9Flar%C4%B1n%C4%B1n_evi.jpg/228px-Ta%C4%9F%C4%B1yev_qarda%C5%9Flar%C4%B1n%C4%B1n_evi.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ta%C4%9F%C4%B1yev_qarda%C5%9Flar%C4%B1n%C4%B1n_evi.jpg) [Nizami Street](/wiki/Nizami_Street "Nizami Street") is considered to be one of the most popular tourist attractions in Baku

The city is listed 48th in the 2011 [list](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_cities_for_expatriate_employees "List of most expensive cities for expatriate employees") of the most expensive cities in the world conducted by the [Mercer Human Resource Consulting](/wiki/Mercer_Human_Resource_Consulting "Mercer Human Resource Consulting").^[\[98\]](#cite_note-103)^ [Nizami Street](/wiki/Nizami_Street "Nizami Street"), also known as Targovaya, and the [Neftchilar Avenue](/wiki/Neftchilar_Avenue "Neftchilar Avenue"), a street known for being home to many luxury and high fashion shops such as [Gucci](/wiki/Gucci "Gucci"), [Dolce \& Gabbana](/wiki/Dolce_%26_Gabbana "Dolce & Gabbana"), [Tom Ford](/wiki/Tom_Ford "Tom Ford"), [Burberry](/wiki/Burberry "Burberry"), [Celine](/wiki/Celine_(brand) "Celine (brand)"), are among the most expensive streets in the world.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-104)^ Monthly expenses for a single person in Baku are estimated to be around 945 manat without rent ($555 USD), which is significantly lower in comparison to other countries.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-105)^ For example, average cost of living for a person in [Los Angeles](/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), [California](/wiki/California "California"), is about $1308 USD,^[\[101\]](#cite_note-106)^ while in [Seoul](/wiki/Seoul "Seoul"), [South Korea](/wiki/South_Korea "South Korea"), its $1074 USD.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-107)^ Living costs in Baku per person are below average when comparing to other developed countries, however, average reported salary of a Bakuvian sits at 997 manat, or about $586 USD.^[\[103\]](#cite_note-108)^{#cite_ref-108}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Culture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Baku_15_16_31_090000.jpeg/187px-Baku_15_16_31_090000.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Baku_15_16_31_090000.jpeg) [Inner City of Baku](/wiki/Old_City_(Baku) "Old City (Baku)") is the oldest area of the capital

Baku, often referred to as the "[Paris of the East](/wiki/Paris_of_the_East "Paris of the East")," is a city where [Eastern](/wiki/Eastern_world "Eastern world") and [Western](/wiki/Western_world "Western world") cultural traditions coexist.^[\[104\]](#cite_note-109)^ The city's core is the historic center, known as [Icheri Sheher](/wiki/Old_City_(Baku) "Old City (Baku)") or the Inner City, commonly referred to as the Old City, which contains various landmarks dating back to at least the 12th century. Among these are the [Maiden Tower](/wiki/Maiden_Tower_(Baku) "Maiden Tower (Baku)") and the [Shirvanshahs' Palace](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Shirvanshahs "Palace of the Shirvanshahs").^[\[105\]](#cite_note-110)^ These buildings reflect the city's history and the [Asian architectural styles](/wiki/History_of_Asian_art "History of Asian art") that have influenced Baku's development. The city's skyline showcases a blend of traditional and [contemporary architecture](/wiki/Contemporary_architecture "Contemporary architecture"), with places like [Baku Boulevard](/wiki/Baku_Boulevard "Baku Boulevard") and [Fountains Square](/wiki/Fountains_Square,_Baku "Fountains Square, Baku") presenting a harmonious mix of historic and modern design elements. The urban landscape of Baku is characterized by a diverse range of buildings that combine the charm of the past with the innovation of the present.^[\[106\]](#cite_note-111)^^[\[107\]](#cite_note-112)^^[\[108\]](#cite_note-113)^ Baku also has a variety of museums and galleries, including the [National Art Museum of Azerbaijan](/wiki/National_Art_Museum_of_Azerbaijan "National Art Museum of Azerbaijan") and the [National Museum of History of Azerbaijan](/wiki/National_Museum_of_History_of_Azerbaijan "National Museum of History of Azerbaijan"), which display both [traditional Azerbaijani and contemporary art](/wiki/Azerbaijani_art "Azerbaijani art"). The city maintains certain traditional crafts such as [carpet-weaving](/wiki/Knotted-pile_carpet "Knotted-pile carpet") and pottery, of which majority are displayed in [Azerbaijan National Carpet Museum](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Carpet_Museum "Azerbaijan Carpet Museum"), with older techniques still practiced. Baku's theater scene includes institutions like the [Azerbaijan State Academic Opera and Ballet Theater](/wiki/Azerbaijan_State_Academic_Opera_and_Ballet_Theater "Azerbaijan State Academic Opera and Ballet Theater") and the [Azerbaijan State Academic National Drama Theatre](/wiki/Azerbaijan_State_Academic_National_Drama_Theatre "Azerbaijan State Academic National Drama Theatre"), which host both local and international performances. Music is an important part of Baku's cultural landscape, with mugham being a traditional genre of music that has been recognized by [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") as part of the [Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity](/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists "UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists"), which was proclaimed to be a "Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity."^[\[109\]](#cite_note-114)^ The city also has a diverse music scene, with genres such as [pop](/wiki/Azerbaijani_pop_music "Azerbaijani pop music"), [rock](/wiki/Azerbaijani_rock "Azerbaijani rock"), and [jazz](/wiki/Azerbaijani_jazz "Azerbaijani jazz") being represented. Additionally, Baku hosts events like the [Baku International Jazz Festival](/wiki/Baku_International_Jazz_Festival "Baku International Jazz Festival") and the Baku International Film Festival.^[\[110\]](#cite_note-115)^^[\[111\]](#cite_note-116)^{#cite_ref-116}

In 2007, the [Heydar Aliyev Cultural Centre](/wiki/Heydar_Aliyev_Cultural_Centre "Heydar Aliyev Cultural Centre"), designed by [Pritzker Prize](/wiki/Pritzker_Prize "Pritzker Prize")-winning architect [Zaha Hadid](/wiki/Zaha_Hadid "Zaha Hadid"), was opened.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-117)^ Baku also has many museums such as [Baku Museum of Modern Art](/wiki/Baku_Museum_of_Modern_Art "Baku Museum of Modern Art") and [National Museum of History](/wiki/National_Museum_of_History_of_Azerbaijan "National Museum of History of Azerbaijan"), most notably featuring historical artifacts and art. Many of the city's cultural sites were celebrated in 2009 when Baku was designated an Islamic Culture Capital.^[\[113\]](#cite_note-118)^ Baku was chosen to host the [Eurovision Dance Contest](/wiki/Eurovision_Dance_Contest "Eurovision Dance Contest") 2010. It has also become the first city to host the first [European Games](/wiki/European_Games "European Games") in [2015](/wiki/2015_European_Games "2015 European Games").^[\[114\]](#cite_note-119)^{#cite_ref-119}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d3/Heydar_Aliyev_Cultural_Center.jpg/220px-Heydar_Aliyev_Cultural_Center.jpg)](/wiki/File:Heydar_Aliyev_Cultural_Center.jpg) [Heydar Aliyev Cultural Center](/wiki/Heydar_Aliyev_Cultural_Center "Heydar Aliyev Cultural Center")

#### Absheron Museum of History and Local Studies {#Absheron_Museum_of_History_and_Local_Studies}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Absheron Museum of History and Local Studies")\]

The **Absheron Museum of History and Local Studies** ([Azerbaijani](/wiki/Azerbaijani_language "Azerbaijani language"): *Abşeron Tarix-Diyarşünaslıq Muzeyi* ) started its activities on 21 November 1983. The area of the museum, which was thoroughly renovated in 2015, is 296 square meters and consists of 5 halls. Currently, about 3000 exhibits are preserved in the museum and 1800 items are displayed in the exposition. Exhibits reflecting the history, geography, nature, everyday life and culture of Absheron region are preserved in the museum.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-122)^^[\[118\]](#cite_note-123)^ The museum consists of 4 halls, 1 fund room and 1 room for employees. The exhibition area is 250 square meters, the manager's room is 1 square meter, the fund room is 10 square meters, and the staff room is 25 square meters. In 2018, the number of visitors to the museum was 1,932.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-124)^{#cite_ref-124}

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Architecture")\]  
Main article: [Architecture in Baku](/wiki/Architecture_in_Baku "Architecture in Baku")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Maiden_Tower_in_Baku_2015.jpg/220px-Maiden_Tower_in_Baku_2015.jpg)](/wiki/File:Maiden_Tower_in_Baku_2015.jpg) [Maiden Tower](/wiki/Maiden_Tower_(Baku) "Maiden Tower (Baku)") in [Old Baku](/wiki/Old_City_(Baku) "Old City (Baku)"), a [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO") [World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site") built in the 11th--12th century, recognised as the symbol of the city. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Baku%2C_Azerbaiy%C3%A1n%2C_2016-09-26%2C_DD_207-209_PAN.jpg/220px-Baku%2C_Azerbaiy%C3%A1n%2C_2016-09-26%2C_DD_207-209_PAN.jpg)](/wiki/File:Baku,_Azerbaiy%C3%A1n,_2016-09-26,_DD_207-209_PAN.jpg) [Multani Caravanserai](/wiki/Multani_Caravanserai "Multani Caravanserai"), Baku

Baku has wildly varying architecture, ranging from the [Old City](/wiki/Old_City_(Baku) "Old City (Baku)") core to modern buildings and the spacious layout of Baku port. Many of the city's landmarks were built during the early 20th century, when architectural elements of the European styles were combined in [eclectic](/wiki/Eclecticism "Eclecticism") style.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-125)^ Baku has an original and unique appearance, earning it a reputation as the *Paris of the East* .^[\[121\]](#cite_note-126)^ Baku joined [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO")'s [Network of Creative Cities](/wiki/Creative_Cities_Network "Creative Cities Network") as a Design City on 31 October 2019 on the occasion of World Cities' Day.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-127)^{#cite_ref-127}  

#### Hamams {#Hamams}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Hamams")\]

There are a number of ancient [hamams](/wiki/Hammam "Hammam") in Baku dating back to the 12th, 14th and 18th centuries. Hamams play a very important role in the architectural appearance of Baku.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-128)^{#cite_ref-128}  

##### Teze Bey Hamam {#Teze_Bey_Hamam}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Teze Bey Hamam")\]

Teze Bey is the most popular hamam (traditional Islamic bath) in Baku. It was built in 1886 in the centre of Baku, and in 2003 it was fully restored and modernised. Along with its modern amenities, Teze Bey features a swimming pool and architectural details inspired by Oriental, Russian and Finnish baths.  

##### Gum Hamam {#Gum_Hamam}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Gum Hamam")\]

Gum Hamam was discovered during archaeological excavations underneath the sand; hence the name: Gum hamam (sand bath). It was built sometime during the 12th--14th centuries.  

##### Bairamali hamam {#Bairamali_hamam}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Bairamali hamam")\]

In ancient times, Bairamali Hamam was called "Bey Hamam". The original structure was built sometime during the 12th--14th centuries and was reconstructed in 1881.  

##### Agha Mikayil Hamam {#Agha_Mikayil_Hamam}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Agha Mikayil Hamam")\]

Agha Mikayil Hamam was constructed in the 18th century by Haji Agha Mikayil on Kichik Gala Street in the Old City (Icherisheher). It is still operating in its ancient setting. The Hamam is open to women on Mondays and Fridays and to men on the other days of the week.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-129)^{#cite_ref-129}  

#### Modern architecture {#Modern_architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Baku&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Modern architecture")\]

Late modern and postmodern architecture began to appear in the early 2000s. With economic development, old buildings such as Atlant House were razed to make way for new ones. Buildings with all-glass shells have appeared around the city, the most prominent examples being the International Mugham Center, [Azerbaijan Tower](/wiki/Azerbaijan_Tower "Azerbaijan Tower"), [Heydar Aliyev Cultural Centre](/w/index.php?title=Heydar_Aliyev_Centre&action=edit&redlink=1 "Heydar Aliyev Centre (page does not exist)"), [Flame Towers](/wiki/Flame_Towers "Flame Towers"), [Baku Crystal Hall](/wiki/Baku_Crystal_Hall "Baku Crystal Hall"), [Baku White City](/wiki/Baku_White_City "Baku White City"), [SOCAR Tower](/wiki/SOCAR_Tower "SOCAR Tower") and [DENIZ Mall](/w/index.php?title=DENIZ_Mall&action=edit&redlink=1 "DENIZ Mall (page does not exist)"). These projects also caught the attention of international media as notable programmes such as [Discovery Channel](/wiki/Discovery_Channel "Discovery Channel")'s [Extreme Engineering](/wiki/Extreme_Engineering "Extreme Engineering") did pieces focusing in on changes to the city.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-130)^{#cite_ref-130}

The Old City of Baku, also known as the Walled City of Baku, refers to the ancient Baku settlement. Most of the walls and towers, strengthened after the Russian conquest in 1806, survived. This section is picturesque, with its maze of narrow alleys and ancient buildings: the cobbled streets past the [Palace of the Shirvanshahs](/wiki/Palace_of_the_Shirvanshahs "Palace of the Shirvanshahs"), two [caravansaries](/wiki/Caravanserai "Caravanserai"), the baths and the [Juma Mosque](/wiki/Juma_Mosque_(Baku) "Juma Mosque (Baku)") (which used to house the [Azerbaijan National Carpet and Arts Museum](/wiki/Azerbaijan_National_Carpet_Museum "Azerbaijan National Carpet Museum") but is now a mosque again). The old town core also has dozens of small mosques, often without any particular sign to distinguish them as such.

In 2003, UNESCO placed the Inner City on the [List of World Heritage in Danger](/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_in_Danger "List of World Heritage in Danger"), citing damage from a [November 2000 earthquake](/wiki/2000_Baku_earthquake "2000 Baku earthquake"), poor conservation as well as "dubious" restoration efforts.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-131)^ In 2009 the Inner City was removed from the List of World Heritage in Danger.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}
